name: Sesame Rice
history: Sesame Rice, known as Ellu Sadam in Tamil Nadu, is a traditional South Indian dish. It's particularly popular in Tamil Nadu and Karnataka. This dish is often prepared during festivals and auspicious occasions, with sesame seeds being the star ingredient.
description: Sesame Rice is a flavorful and aromatic dish made with roasted sesame seeds, spices, and cooked rice. It's known for its nutty flavor and is often eaten as a main course or a side dish. Sesame seeds add a unique taste and are believed to have health benefits.

equipment.name: pan
equipment.description: For roasting sesame seeds and spices.

instructions.title: Roast Sesame Seeds
instructions.description: Dry roast the sesame seeds in a pan until they turn golden brown and aromatic. Set aside to cool.

instructions.title: Grind Sesame Seeds
instructions.description: Once cooled, grind the roasted sesame seeds to a coarse powder.

instructions.title: Prepare Tempering
instructions.description: Heat oil in the same pan. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, dry red chilies, asafoetida, and curry leaves. SautÃ© until the dal turns golden brown.

instructions.title: Mix with Rice
instructions.description: Add the ground sesame powder and salt to the tempered spices. Mix well. Add this mixture to the cooked rice and mix gently until well combined.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Sesame Rice warm or at room temperature.

tips: Ensure the sesame seeds are not over-roasted as they can turn bitter.
Adjust the number of red chilies according to your spice preference.
variations: Add a pinch of jaggery for a hint of sweetness.
Incorporate a handful of roasted peanuts for a crunchy texture.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Reheat gently in a microwave or on the stove, adding a little water if the rice has dried out.

presentationTips: Garnish with additional sesame seeds and a sprig of curry leaves.
Serve in a traditional bowl with a side of yogurt or raita.
